original_title: ADB, World Bank leads as Sri Lanka gets US$1.5bn in loans in 2023
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s foreign creditors had disbursed 1.5 billion US dollars in the nine months to September 2023, with Asian Development Bank giving the most support, official data show.
The ADB had disbursed 529 million US dollars up to September 2023, the World Bank 442.8 million US dollars and the International Monetary Fund 343.7 million US dollars.
India provided 142.5 million US dollars, the Netherlands 7.4 million US dollars and the Saudi fund for economic development 5.6 million US dollars.
The Asian Infrastructure Development Fund gave 22.9 million US dollars.
The agencies and countries also gave 10.6 million US dollars in grants with the World Bank giving 8.4 million US dollars and Germany 2.1 million.
Some countries do not give fresh loans to after a country defaults but will resume after debt is restructured.
Multilateral lenders start budget support loans after when an IMF program starts. This time IMF loans are also budget support loans going to the Treasury instead of to the central bank.
Defaulting countries are expected to continue repayments to multilateral agencies.

Up to September Sri Lanka had made debt service payments of 912.8 million US dollars of which 631.9 million US dollars was for principal repayments and 280.9 million was for interest. (Colombo/Dec04/2023)
